Pesto is a more generic Italian term that describes a wide variety of puréed sauces, traditionally made using a mortar and pestle.  The most famous, and the one we're talking about here, is pesto alla genovese, from the Ligurian city of Genoa and its environs.

conversation.utterance: But let me answer your other question as well.

Pine nuts, also called piñón () or pinoli (), sometimes called pignoli in the US, are the edible seeds of pines (family Pinaceae, genus "Pinus"). About 20 species of pine produce seeds large enough to be worth harvesting; in other pines, the seeds are also edible, but are too small to be of notable value as a human food. Throughout Europe and Middle East the pine nuts used are traditionally from "Pinus pinea" (stone pine). They are easily distinguished from the Asian pine nuts by their more slender shape and more homogeneous flesh. Because of the lower price, Asian pine nuts are also often used, especially in cheaper preparations. Pine nuts contain thiamine (vitamin B) and protein.

Pine nuts are not actually nuts. They are seeds found inside the structure of the pine cone. Technically, sunflower seeds would provide the most similar flavor when looking for a pine nut substitution in traditional recipes. Sesame seeds would also offer a solution to those with nut allergies that don't have pine nuts on hand.

provenance.page_title: What is a good pine nut substitute for pesto?

Sesame seeds would also offer a solution to those with nut allergies that don't have pine nuts on hand.

Also: Did you know that pine nuts have long been a dietary staple in some Native American tribes?

provenance.page_title: Pine nut
provenance.paragraph_text: Pine nuts have long been a dietary staple in some Native American tribes. Today, though some tribes still use pine nuts in traditional cooking, others use the hard outer shell of the pine nut as a bead for decorative purposes in traditional regalia and jewelry. In the Great Basin area of the US, collecting pine nuts is a protected right through state law and treaty.

if you dont know that is ok

Basil is sensitive to cold, with best growth in hot, dry conditions. It behaves as an annual if there is any chance of a frost. However, due to its popularity, basil is cultivated in many countries around the world. Production areas include countries in the Mediterranean area, those in the temperate zone, and others in subtropical climates. Although basil grows best outdoors, it can be grown indoors in a pot and, like most herbs, will do best on a sun-facing windowsill. It should be kept away from extremely cold drafts, and grows best in strong sunlight, therefore a greenhouse or row cover is ideal if available. It can, however, be grown even in a basement, under fluorescent lights.

The Ligurian oil, for instance, is buttery and rounded in flavor, and a good choice for your pesto.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Is the Best Olive Oil for Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: But, while the Ligurian oil came out on top, being more buttery and rounded in flavor, we all agreed that the differences were incredibly subtle.

conversation.utterance: But as long as you're using a decent, somewhat mild olive oil, your pesto is going to be good; if you feel like using an even higher-quality, not-too-spicy oil, whether Ligurian or not, it may be subtly better.

is it best fresh or after storage
Give me a moment

From the moment you finished making the pesto, it may start to lose flavor. Freezing halts the deterioration of the highly volatile aromatics, particularly basil, that give pesto much of its vibrancy. Based on this, fresh pesto tastes the best.

provenance.page_title: Pantry Essentials: All About Pesto
provenance.paragraph_text: A jar of pesto should be stored in the refrigerator after opening and lasts for two to three weeks, but it may start to lose flavor from the moment you open the jar. If you can find it, frozen pesto offers the closest commercial approximation of home-made pesto's freshness, because freezing halts the deterioration of the highly volatile aromatics, particularly basil, that give pesto much of its vibrancy.
